This game gives me heavy OG DOOM vibes, especially the final sequence of the game...for those of you who played OG DOOM, you'll know -exactly- what I'm talking about.

Time for the good, the bad, and the ugly.

The Good:

You piece the story of the game together gradually, and it's done without cutscenes or dramatic flair...it feels organic, and follows a logical sequence of events.  The gameplay mechanics are insanely fun, and by the time you get far enough into a mission you really start to feel like a badass.  The fact that there are persistent upgrades means that you have a reason to switch to harder difficulties and do more, because you won't be at a crippling disadvantage.  The gameplay is extremely well balanced, and it was easy to tell the team cared a -lot- about their product.  

And for what voice actors there are, you guys did -awesome-.  

The Bad:

A bit colorful considering the situation going on, and the music fits but can be a bit repetitive.  Still, if these are the worst points of the game, this is nothing to worry about.

The Ugly:

Sometimes when you enter a level section for the first time, you can get basically insta-nuked in the first room.  Annoying.

All in all, I HIGHLY recommend this game, and supporting further projects by the people who made this.   The Co-op play is just the chef's kiss on top of an already excellent title.  AAA fun without the the AAA price.

For the devs, if you read this:
The meta-progression is nice, it is what keeps games alive, but this game desperately needs deeper and more choice oriented perks. You can max out everything with no branching of skill trees and no synergistic interactions, which means every build becomes largely the same concept with a slight elemental twist. I think anyone who has played the game a fair bit will agree when we say that going a little more in depth with progression and build variance would be an absolutely massive step to making this game contend with the big roguelikes. We crave buildcrafting.

Additionally, some better replayability would also be much appreciated. The endless modes kinda just become the same wave over and over with little to no changes roughly 30 minutes into a run. Something like additional enemy modifiers synergizing with floor/room modifiers could do wonders on creating more unique interactions.

I know these critiques might SEEM like the game isn't worth getting, but in reality it is. At a minimum you should be able to get 30+ hours of really satisfying and fun gunplay and movement, so at it's relatively low price it is 100% worth the grab.

The game is super fun though and offers a challenging experience on the Expert and Nightmare Difficulties.  The weapon variety is awesome and offers you a variety of options/play styles ranging from melee, grenade, sniper quick-scoping, semi-auto, burst, and fully auto sub/assault/light machine guns.  Match your weapons, health/armor, and perks in the right way, you will shred your enemies most of the time unless you encounter a crazy/unfair room as I mentioned earlier. If you like run and gun games that require some thought and strategy, then this is a must have in your collection.  Or if you want an aim trainer that requires fast movement, reaction time, target switching, light tracking, and fires back, this is a solid game for that.  For me, this game is an 8/10 as it stands. There are two words that come to mind when I think of this game: competent, and brain-dead. The game feels well put together and is decent fun at first, but quickly devolves into monotony and tedium.

On the positive side, the gunplay is good fun. Guns themselves are a bit standard but feel punchy and responsive. Run-to-run upgrades, particularly the elements, are pretty interesting. Synergies introduced later offer good reasons to be selective with your items and aim for particular loadouts. There are a handful of fun challenge levels too, particularly the one where you use the spear melee weapon for the whole run.

Unfortunately, there are far more negatives. For starters, this game is extremely bland. Visual style and environments are drab, enemy designs feel stock-standard by-and-large, guns don't offer any interesting gameplay quirks, affixes are basic and just contribute to a "numbers go up" mentality, item portraits are too visually identical, weapon skins are just palette swaps most of which are not impressive, and the plot is boring and barely noticeable. Bosses are completely forgettable and offer no real challenge. Most of your runs are going to just blend together in your mind because there is genuinely nothing that stands out enough between them. Sure, there are difficulty settings for harder missions, but if your standard difficulty isn't engaging, multiplying some numbers isn't going to fix that.

Every single upgrade in the meta-progression tree has it's own currency which makes the menus a cluttered nightmare, but you earn everything passively so you are basically just clicking buttons until your currency runs out, completely canceling out any complexities. My buddy and I had completely upgraded everything by the time we finished the available missions, and honestly, we didn't really notice much change to game from this. And for some baffling reason, the new systems that they have added in later zones of the game have not been retroactively worked into previous ones, making zone 3 feel like a far more complete game experience, and zone 1 feel like an empty beta build. Also, the game tries to inject comedy and intrigue through logs and character quips, but the writing is terrible and the vocal performance from the main character is the epitome of mediocre. 

If you are looking for a way to kill some time with a friend, then this game will give you that, but it's never going to be more than just that: killing time. Like I said, it is certainly competent, but there are so many other roguelikes, even ones that play very similar to this one, that will respect your time so much more.

The game is a ton of fun for the most part with a wide variety of viable build paths and playstyles. Some of the nightmare content needs a balance pass, but still very enjoyable for the most part.

Lately however (since the latest patch as far as I can tell), the game will disconnect from the server after playing for about an hour for no discernable reason and completely refuse to reconnect until the game is restarted. If you're playing strictly solo, it's not a big deal, but it completely breaks a multiplayer run. It's not specific to my internet connection either, because the exact same thing happens when I play from other locations with my laptop, and with all of my friends scattered around the country no matter who is hosting. The game didn't have the disconnection issue at all until somewhat recently despite always having sub-par netcode. The slowly ballooning latency could be suffered enough to still enjoy the game, but the server drops completely kill the experience.

From what I understand, this is a reskin of an extraction shooter made by the company that abandoned Tribes.  Nevertheless, I have no ties to that game nor the company so, with that out of the way, I will give my objective opinion.

This is a rogue lite.  It is not a very deep rogue lite, but it still scratches that itch.  The gunplay is solid, reminds me of MW3 (2011).  The music is decent, if not forgettable house techno music.  The perks are somewhat interesting as they help with progress but you will end up using the same beneficial ones over and over again.  The same strategy applies to every run.  I use the same guns every run.  But for me, that is okay.  I enjoy knowing what to expect.  There is a quiet comfort, almost like your favorite snack that gets boring after awhile, however, you still enjoy it even though it does not have the same impact it initially had.  That is this game.  It does not do anything exceptionally but what it does, is very good, good enough for a mindless shooter that turns my mind off for the time I play it.  Money well spent for that feature.  Also, runs very well on Steam Deck, this is surprising considering Unreal Engine struggles on the platform.  Kudos for achieving that.  

Now, the caveats.  First, the level design is blah.  From bland colored environments to neon saturated hallways that feel like a big closet, I find them forgettable and almost ai generated.  Second, that voice actor is horrible.  I have gotten used to his dry, almost redneck type voice, but his delivery is awkward and he really has nothing of interest to say.  The story is ‚Äúyawn‚Äù, you are out in space, stranded on a military ship and have no idea ‚Äúyawn‚Äù of your origins or how you got there‚Ä¶‚Äùyawn‚Äù‚Ä¶Shoot your way through to find out why and how you got here and what happened to the passengers‚Ä¶.zzzzzz‚Ä¶.‚Äùsnoring‚Äù‚Ä¶Oh Androids have taken over with some bio freaks‚Ä¶oh man, that is elementary writing.  Just cringe.  Also, back to the voice acting‚Ä¶The main character is awful but so are all the other characters whose ‚Äúlogs‚Äù you pick up.  I believe I would be a better voice actor.  These people are not even trying.  No inflection.  No emphasis, just blah.  Makes me think that (along with the levels) this may be AI as well.  

Overall, and taking all of these things into consideration, I have still enjoyed my time with this game.  It is a solid shooter that allows me to shut off my mind for my 45 to 90 minute runs.  No story or character investment.  Just solid shooting.  So yes, I would recommend.  Do not expect much in return though.  Look at it as a couple nights of cheap entertainment - or a case of beer. Before the 1.0 release of this game. The difficulty on nightmare was quite challenging. Like I'd die a good amount of times, but eventually I could get through even on single player.
Now, after the 1.0 release, The difficulty on nightmare is ridiculous now. Even with a full squad of three players, getting decent weapons, and even good perks. The types of enemies the come out seem way to difficult for that point in the rounds that you barely have any gear. The amount of enemies is high, but tolerable unless they're all spread out and hitting you from all angles to where you can't get any environmental cover.
Some enemies are also unbalanced I feel. The smaller flying bugs have way too much health. Most flying enemies are also hyper accurate even though they also have height advantage to shoot you over cover. With the deadshot eyes also hitting too hard for being so accurate and getting to fire off multiple shots even though their bipedal counterpart only gets to fire off one very accurate, very fast, very very heavy hitting shot.
The orange walking flame thrower spiders also are and unbalanced combination of too fast movement speed, too hard hitting, too rapidly hitting.

A majority of this unbalance almost absolutely pushes you into taking a crowd control element. Ice for Freeze, Void to maybe get roots, or Psionic slam. Chose fire, you're screwed. Lighting? maybe you'll get stuns, but they're unreliable. Even the void singularity and root isn't that powerful. And don't get me started on the freaking black hole spiders. The other spiders suicide bomb after being triggered, but the void spiders AOE is so big that you commonly get yo-yoed around and try to dash, but can't escape the area of effect. Which on nightmare is basically a death sentence if you didn't kill those things far enough away from you to not get sucked in.

Also, the whole ghost thing in zone three is nifty, but ultimately the bane of existence for splash damage users. Kill too many ghosts at once? you're probably gonna be able to dodge one then get hit and killed by the rest as their charges are staggered directly to your location. Plus the huge sword beam attacks go through walls, which is hard, but manageable when shoved in some of the tight quarters of zone 3.

Another big thing I feel makes nightmare unbalanced is it feels like the enemies back in zone one have been tweaked up as if you're suppose to have the additional power of superior items and synergies. And zone 2 feels like you would need the synergies to make things more manageable.

A lot of this could be tapered out and made more manageable if we had extra levels of basic upgrades to keep upgrading even if the costs start get a bit steep. I have rough 70,000 tech and nothing to spend it on. I've maxed out all the base upgrades and superior items. A core mechanic to rouge like games is having a lot of upgrades to buy to make the following runs just a little bit easier each time. After about 20 hours of gameplay, I've had all base perks maxed out and most of the superior items that I go for on multiple different build ideas maxed out. At about 30 hours even after the update. I had all the extra base upgrades maxed out and the rest of all the superior items maxed out. The only reason I keep playing is trying to beat levels on nightmare. Which I've had to rebeat several because after the update, my progress on those levels were deleted.

Overall it's a good game until you reach expert solo or nightmare even with 3 people. The balance of too many factors, just makes the game unbeatable unless you're an absolute sweat player on solo with great loot and perk rolls. And with more people it is still incredibly easy to get yourself killed or do something that causes your team mate to be suddenly overwhelmed and killed.

There are two words that come to mind when I think of this game: competent, and brain-dead. The game feels well put together and is decent fun at first, but quickly devolves into monotony and tedium.

On the positive side, the gunplay is good fun. Guns themselves are a bit standard but feel punchy and responsive. Run-to-run upgrades, particularly the elements, are pretty interesting. Synergies introduced later offer good reasons to be selective with your items and aim for particular loadouts. There are a handful of fun challenge levels too, particularly the one where you use the spear melee weapon for the whole run.

Unfortunately, there are far more negatives. For starters, this game is extremely bland. Visual style and environments are drab, enemy designs feel stock-standard by-and-large, guns don't offer any interesting gameplay quirks, affixes are basic and just contribute to a "numbers go up" mentality, item portraits are too visually identical, weapon skins are just palette swaps most of which are not impressive, and the plot is boring and barely noticeable. Bosses are completely forgettable and offer no real challenge. Most of your runs are going to just blend together in your mind because there is genuinely nothing that stands out enough between them. Sure, there are difficulty settings for harder missions, but if your standard difficulty isn't engaging, multiplying some numbers isn't going to fix that.

Every single upgrade in the meta-progression tree has it's own currency which makes the menus a cluttered nightmare, but you earn everything passively so you are basically just clicking buttons until your currency runs out, completely canceling out any complexities. My buddy and I had completely upgraded everything by the time we finished the available missions, and honestly, we didn't really notice much change to game from this. And for some baffling reason, the new systems that they have added in later zones of the game have not been retroactively worked into previous ones, making zone 3 feel like a far more complete game experience, and zone 1 feel like an empty beta build. Also, the game tries to inject comedy and intrigue through logs and character quips, but the writing is terrible and the vocal performance from the main character is the epitome of mediocre. 

If you are looking for a way to kill some time with a friend, then this game will give you that, but it's never going to be more than just that: killing time. Like I said, it is certainly competent, but there are so many other roguelikes, even ones that play very similar to this one, that will respect your time so much more.

Synergies introduced later offer good reasons to be selective with your items and aim for particular loadouts. There are a handful of fun challenge levels too, particularly the one where you use the spear melee weapon for the whole run.

Unfortunately, there are far more negatives. For starters, this game is extremely bland. Visual style and environments are drab, enemy designs feel stock-standard by-and-large, guns don't offer any interesting gameplay quirks, affixes are basic and just contribute to a "numbers go up" mentality, item portraits are too visually identical, weapon skins are just palette swaps most of which are not impressive, and the plot is boring and barely noticeable. Bosses are completely forgettable and offer no real challenge. Most of your runs are going to just blend together in your mind because there is genuinely nothing that stands out enough between them. Sure, there are difficulty settings for harder missions, but if your standard difficulty isn't engaging, multiplying some numbers isn't going to fix that.

If you are looking for a way to kill some time with a friend, then this game will give you that, but it's never going to be more than just that: killing time. Like I said, it is certainly competent, but there are so many other roguelikes, even ones that play very similar to this one, that will respect your time so much more.

- dropped items and damage numbers are very obstructive
- the game doesn't do much that other roguelikes don't already do or are doing better
- early game missions are very anti buildmaking because they're shorter length, you have less options as everything is locked behind later missions, and you have either no rerolls or very few rerolls
- bosses are basically nothing with a very boring attack pattern
- some elements feel like bloat and only exist to pad out the upgrades (void/plasma)
- metagame upgrades consist of extremely boring +X% upgrades that only exist to exist rather than provide meaningful changes to gameplay
- main character is horrendously written and has some of the worst lines of dialogue I've heard in any form of media, had to turn off dialogue audio just to not close the game
- very few good upgrades which just results in you running the same couple of perks every run. upgrades like the grenade or melee related ones are entirely useless when in comparison to just running the same elemental/gun/health upgrades every time
- majority of buffs in the game have a very abnoxious limit to them rather than having lesser effects. main examples I can think of are any expended ammo related buffs

overall the game is an okay roguelike to turn your brain off but with other actually good (and AI-less) alternatives it's not worth buying

I really tried to play this game, but I was forced to refund it with nearly an hour of tracked running time and 0 seconds of actual playing time.
It's DirectX12. This game supports only DX12, and if there is only a single graphics API you support, then it'd be Vulkan. Okay, maybe DX11 if you are willing to bite the compatibility bullet. DX12 only? Yeah...that is asking for trouble, and I spent days troubleshooting including a full DDU reinstall and multiple drivers, with a fairly standard W10+RX 5700 XT setup, but no.
(Note, this is the first game in a decade that I straight up didn't get to play at all, it's a complete outlier.)

The game might be amazing but if it's unplayable due to poor technical choices, what can I say. So be warned, if your system already had beef with DX12, maybe don't bother until the devs get around to addressing the situation.

Has some amazing gunplay, but that is all it has going for it.
The level design is the definition of bare minimum; just a bunch of flat, empty rooms connected with narrow hallways. Easily the weakest aspect of the game.

The gameplay loop consists of replaying the same stages on incrementing difficulties, but the difficulty balancing rapidly goes from satisfying to tedious. You don't have to play for long to reach the point where your character instantly combusts from an enemy breathing on you too hard. Mix this with the level design and half the perks being so laughably bad you'll never want to use them, and the game gets very stale very quick.

There are some really questionable enemy design choices in Act 3. Spamming half a dozen copies of an enemy in a 5x6 room that can make multiple invincible clones, fill the room with projectiles, and shoot through walls is a bit ridiculous.

There's not enough meta progression, and it honestly feels like such an after thought. There's ten's of hours of content but you'll have all your passive perks maxed out within the first 10 hours, and the buffs you get from them are so negligible on higher difficulties. 

The missions where you're forced to use a single weapon get repetitive very quickly. Finishing these missions reward you by permanently unlocking the weapon, but 2/3 of the missions restrict you to using one weapon, so it's a pretty lacklustre reward.

I am very conflicted about this game. Years ago I purchased a game called Starsiege Deadzone, because it looked like a really funny battle royal/ extraction shooter set in space. I had so much fun playing it and occasionally missed it after the playtests, but never checked in on it. Going through my steam library recently I noticed this game, which I had no recollection of. As soon as I booted it up I realized this is what the devs turned starsiege deadzone into, and its honestly pretty disappointing. This game, in a vacuum, is fun, but when I am playing it all I can think about is how much more fun I had playing Starsiege. This game should have been a spin off of starsiege for those who don't want a pvp game but still enjoy the other aspects, it should not have completely replaced it. 

So basically if you want to play a FPS space roguelike, I highly recommend this game, but as someone who paid for a pvp extraction shooter and instead got a roguelike, I can't recommend it.
